technical-data.invention-title: Système de montage de tableau blanc

description.p: This application claims priority to U.S. Provisional Patent Application No. 60/982,321, filed October 24, 2007.
The field of the invention is for a mounting system, and is applicable to a device to support a display, such as a whiteboard.

Teaching professionals utilize many different educational tools to illustrate concepts and assist student understanding and development. Instructors have used chalkboards for decades to illustrate visual characteristics to a students to help them visualize and understand information. A chalkboard utilizes a piece of chalk, usually of a lighter color, against a darker color board. The chalk, however, caused dust when used. Chalkboards were also limited in their color range and the visibility of the chalk to a large audience. Whiteboards or dry-erase boards, were subsequently developed to permit an instructor to write on a white colored board with markers of various colors. The marks were then easily removed by wiping them off the surface of the board. The whiteboards are generally easier to use and less messy. The use of whiteboards have proliferated into everyday use in offices, meeting rooms, classrooms, and other environments.

However, one common problem with conventional whiteboards, is that there are essentially only two types: (1) permanently mounted, and (2) portable. The permanently affixed whiteboard acts as a replacement to the chalkboard, but is limited to only that functionality. A portable whiteboard generally has a plurality of feet and a support to hold the board on a wheelable base. Therefore, the whiteboard may be replaced and moved to a new location as needed by the user- The portable whiteboard is generally smaller, and is still cumbersome to set up, remove, and store. Interactive whiteboards are generally even more difficult to transport as they are generally heavier and more delicate because of the additional electronics within the board.

United States patent publication US 6,688,568 B1 describes a fixing device comprising a rod hooked on a wall. However, this publication does not disclose that one end of the rod is curved towards a support surface. United States patent application publication no. US 2009/0101608 A1 describes an interactive white board track system, though not one that is removably hung from a support surface. United States patent application publication no. US 2005/0191611 A1 describes a white board and white board display system. However, this publication does not disclose a rod curved at one end toward a support surface.

United States patent publication no. US 6,328,571 B1 describes a wall mounted rail system with movable boards mounted on tube assemblies, but does not disclose that those tube assemblies are curved, at lower ends thereof, towards the wall such that the wall provides support to them.

The invention provides, in one aspect, a mounting system for supporting a display to a support surface, the system comprising: a top rail configured for attachment to the support surface; a plurality of mounting arms removably attached, by hanging, to the top rail, each mounting arm comprising a first end and a second end, each arm having a longitudinal axis, each arm having a portion at the second end thereof that is curved towards the support surface to support them and each arm including a leveling foot extending from respective terminal ends of the second ends to provide support for each mounting arm against the support surface; and an upper support rail removably attached to the plurality of mounting arms and configured to support the display.

The invention provides in another aspect, a mounting system to a support surface and a display thereon, the method comprising the steps of: securing a top rail to the support surface; coupling an upper support rail and lower support rail to at least one mounting arm, the mounting arm having a first end and a second end, a longitudinal axis and a portion at the second end of the arm curved towards the support surface to support them. The arm including a levelling foot extending from a terminal end of the second end to provide support for the mounting arm against the support surface, wherein the upper support rail includes a cleat facing away from the at least one mounting arms; hanging the at least one mounting arm from the top rail; and
mounting the display by hanging the display from the cleat on the upper support rail and connecting the display to the lower support rail with a hook and loop fastener means.

The mounting system is used to removably attach a display, such as an interactive whiteboard, to a support surface, such as a wall or movable mount. The mounting system may be configured to fit over an existing wall feature, such as a chalk board. The mounting system utilizes a top rail which is secured to the support surface. One or more mounting arms are hung from the top rail. These mounting arms are attached to at least one support rail. Additionally, the support rail supports a display, for example by a cleat. The mounting system may utilize hook and loop fasteners to secure the display to another support rail, or the mounting arm to the support surface. The mounting arm includes a leveling foot to adjust alignment of the mounting system.
An exemplary embodiment further comprises an attachment portion is attached to each of the plurality of mounting arms to hang each of the plurality of mount arms from the top rail.
In an exemplary embodiment, the attachment portion is a clip that hangs from a cleat on the top rail.
The plurality of mounting arms include leveling feet, which allow adjustment of the arms relative to the distance between the support surface and the display.
An exemplary embodiment further comprises a finger cleat configured to attach to the support surface and secure the leveling foot in position.
An exemplary embodiment, further comprises a finger cleat configured to attach to the support wall and designed to secure the mounting arm in place.
In an exemplary embodiment, the plurality of mounting arms are configured to have a contour that fits over an existing wall feature.
An exemplary embodiment, the plurality of mounting arms include a plurality of coupling locations for adjustment of the a height of the top support rail.
In an exemplary embodiment, the upper support rail includes a cleat to support the display.
In an exemplary embodiment, further comprises a lower support rail attached to the plurality of mounting arms.
In an exemplary embodiment, the lower support rail is removably attached to the display with a hook and loop fastener.
In an exemplary embodiment, the lower support rail is removably attached to the display with an adhesive.
In an exemplary embodiment, the display is an interactive whiteboard.
In an exemplary embodiment, the lower rail attaches to the device through a hook and loop fastener means.
In an exemplary embodiment, the two or more mounting arms include a leveling foot.
In an exemplary embodiment, the leveling foot is attached to the support surface by a finger cleat.
In an exemplary embodiment, the display is an interactive whiteboard.

A whiteboard mounting system according to an embodiment of the invention is disclosed. The mounting system includes a top rail attached to a support surface, such as a wall or a portable mount. The top rail supports two or more mounting arms, which removably attach to the top rail. One or more support rails is attached to the mounting arms and to the whiteboard to secure the whiteboard to the support surface. The whiteboard hangs from a top support rail, and is removably attached to a lower support rail through hook and loop fasteners. The mounting arms also include leveling feet to properly position and support the mounting system against the support surface. These leveling feet may be removably attached to the support surface through hook and loop fasteners or with finger cleats.

The mounting system permits easy removal of a board for relocating to, or storing in, various locations. The mounting system may additionally be used to easily accommodate and interchange various sizes, shapes, and kinds of boards, depending on the user's desired requirements.

In the following description of preferred embodiments, reference is made to the accompanying drawings which form a part hereof, and in which it is shown by way of illustration specific embodiments in which the invention can be practiced. It is to be understood that other embodiments can be used and structural changes can be made without departing from the scope of the claimed invention.

Although embodiments of the invention may be described and illustrated herein in terms of whiteboard, and particularly smart boards, it should be understood that the claimed invention is not so limited, but are additionally applicable to any support system. For example, the embodiments of the present invention may be used with chalk boards or bulletin boards. Furthermore, although embodiments of the invention may be described and illustrated herein in terms of educational tools, including whiteboards, it should be understood that embodiments of the invention are also applicable to other industries, such as electronic controls and displays, including audio/video equipment mounting systems.

FIG. 1 illustrates a whiteboard mounting system 100 according to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention. In an exemplary embodiment, the mounting system 100 has a top rail 110 that is attached to a wall or support surface (not shown) for the whiteboard (not shown). The mounting arm 120 is removably attached to the top rail 110. The top rail 110 may include a support protrusion 112 that is configured to mate with an attachment portion 122 of the mounting arm 120. At least one and, alternatively, a plurality, of support rails 130 is/are connected to the mounting arms 120 and support the attached whiteboard. In an embodiment, the whiteboard (not shown) may be removably attached directly to the support rail 130 or may utilize a support feature 132 on the support rail 130.

The support rails 130 are positioned along the mounting arms 120 at a plurality of heights to vertically adjust the whiteboard location. Additionally, the board may be supported at a plurality of positions on the support rails 130 which may permit horizontal adjustment of the board relative to the support rails 130. The mounting arm 120 has at least a first end and a second end. The second end of the mounting arm 120, which is located opposite to the attachment portion 122 and the first end 119 of the mounting arm 120, includes a leveling foot 124 that may adjust the distance from the wall which may ultimately assist in properly aligning the mounting system 100 relative to the wall.

In an exemplary embodiment, the mounting arms 120 may be contoured to fit over an existing wall feature. It is contemplated that the mounting arms 120 may have a convex and/or concave portion which may hold the whiteboard away from the supporting surface, such that a user may install the whiteboard over an existing blackboard. Moreover, the mounting arms 120 may be constructed to be longer than the height of the whiteboard, to permit greater placement options for the whiteboard on the mounting arms 120. Further the extended length of the mounting arms 120 may permit the mounting arms 120 to span and if necessary, exceed the height of the underlying blackboard (not shown). However, it should be understood that the mounting arms 120 may alternatively be configured to have no convex or concave portions, and alternatively be flat against the support wall or within the frame of the whiteboard, to provide different aesthetic and special options.

FIG. 1A illustrates a close up of the support rail 130 whereby the support rail 130 attaches to the mounting arm 120. In an exemplary embodiment, the support rail 130 may attach to the mounting arm 120 at a plurality of locations to permit the vertical adjustment of the whiteboard relative to the mounting arm 120. The support rail 130 may be attached to the mounting arm 120 by any of screws, rivets, pull-pins, friction sliders, and the like. For example, as seen in FIG. 1B, mounting arm 120 includes a plurality of screw holes 126 to allow for attachment of the support rail 130 to the mounting arm 120 via screws 134. In an exemplary embodiment, a plurality of holes are provided to permit a user to adjust the height of the whiteboard.

The support rail 130 may include a support feature 132 that may engage a corresponding feature on the whiteboard. For example, as shown in FIG. 1A, the support feature 132 is a cleat similar to the support protrusion 112 of the top rail 110. In an exemplary embodiment, the support feature 132 may be a cleat that resembles an upside down, half U-shaped hook that engages a corresponding feature on the back of the whiteboard (not shown). The whiteboard may include an upper edge including a lip projected outward then downward to create a mating hook for the support feature 132. In another exemplary embodiment, the support feature 132 of the support rail 130 and the corresponding feature of the whiteboard (not shown) are configured to permit the whiteboard to easily slide in a horizontal direction. A stop may be provided along the support rail 130 or the corresponding feature of the whiteboard to prevent the board from sliding out of its rail or overbalancing the mounting system. It should be understood that a cleat is provided to removably attach the board to the support rail, however, a plurality of different attachment means may be utilized to attach same.

In another alternate embodiment, the mounting system may utilize hook and loop fasteners that may be used in place of the support feature on at least one of the support rails 130. For example, the mounting system 100 may include two support rails 130a and 130b, as seen in FIG. 1. The upper support rail 130a may be attached to the whiteboard with a support feature 132, as described above, while the lower support rail 130b may be attached to the whiteboard with a hook and loop fastener. In this case, the surface of the support rail 130b may have a hook or loop fastener, while the back of the whiteboard has the corresponding loop or hook fastener. The hook and loop fastener may be attached to the support rail or whiteboard by taping, gluing, adhering, bonding, stapling, or other device. Alternatively, for a more permanent connection, the support rail may be adhered to the whiteboard directly through taping, gluing, adhering, bonding, or other device.

FIG. 1B illustrates the lower corner of the mounting system 100 including the mounting arm 120 and leveling foot 124. In an exemplary embodiment, the mounting arms 120 includes a leveling foot 124 to adjust the angle of the mounting system 100. The leveling foot 124 may be an adjustable pad 128. The height of the leveling foot 124 may be adjusted utilizing devices, such as a sliding extension, a screw extension, or the like. The leveling foot 124 may be attached to the mounting arm 120 or another embodiment may be integrally formed with the mounting arm 120. In an exemplary embodiment, the leveling foot may be a cap portion that may be fitted over the end portion 131 of the mounting arm 120. The adjustable pad 128 may be adjusted to properly align the whiteboard mounting system 100.

FIG. 1C illustrates a cut away view of the lower corner of the mounting system 100, including the leveling foot 124 and finger cleat 140, according to an exemplary embodiment of the invention. In an exemplary embodiment, a finger cleat 140 may be mounted to the support surface (not shown) to additionally secure the leveling foot 124 and potentially add further support to the mounting system 100. The finger cleat 140 includes an indention 142 to fit around a neck 129 of the leveling foot 124 between the adjustable pad 128 and the mounting arm 120. The finger cleat 140 may be positioned so that the indention 142 in horizontal, and therefore, locks the mounting system 100 in place once installed. The finger cleat 140 may optionally be installed so the invention 142 faces upwards, and therefore, permits the mounting system 100 to be removed and replaced, repeatedly sliding into the indention from the top side while fitting the mounting system to the top rail. The finger cleat 140 may be secured to the support surface by a screw or nail 144 through hole 146. Other securing devices may be used, such as taping, anchoring, adhering, gluing, bonding, and the like.

In an exemplary embodiment, the system may utilize hook and loop fasteners that may be added to the mounting system 100 for additional stability. The adjustable pad 128 located on the leveling foot 124 of the mounting arm 120 may include a hook or loop fastener surface. A corresponding loop or hook fastener may be adhered to the mounting surface for attaching to its corresponding hook and fastener on the mounting arm 120. The hook and loop fasteners may be adhered, bonded, glued, or otherwise attached to the respective locations.

It is contemplated that the top rail 110 may be made of any sufficiently strong material to support the whiteboard. In an exemplary embodiment, the top hanging rail 110 may be constructed of aluminum that may be sufficiently rigid to support the attached board, but still light in weight to reduce the additional burden on the wall or supporting surface to which the system is attached. The mounting arms 120 may be constructed of steel to provide adequate support strength for the board. The support rails 130 may also be constructed of aluminum to reduce the weight of the mounting system 100. Other materials, for each component, may include metals or metal alloys, such as aluminum, aluminum alloy (e.g. 6063-T5), steel (18ga steel). Strong plastics or other materials may alternatively be used. It should be understood that a plurality of different materials may be utilized, and each component of the system 100 may be constructed of the same or different materials.

FIG. 2 illustrates the mounting system 200 in the unassembled state, according to exemplary embodiments of the invention. In an exemplary embodiment, the mounting system 200 may be provided in a complete kit form which may include an aluminum top rail 210, two 18ga steel mounting arms 220 with steel hanger clips 226, leveler inserts 224, and two aluminum support rails 230. Additionally, the system 200 may include mounting equipment and instructions for assembling the system 200. The mounting system 200 may be designed to secure a smart board to a wall over an existing black board or whiteboard.

To install the top rail 210, the user would place the top rail above the existing chalk board (not shown), and secure the top rail 210 in the desired location. The top rail 210 is attached to a wall (not shown), for example with wall anchors, nails, screws, or other securing devices, depending on the wall characteristics. Then, the support rails 230 are removably attached to the mounting arms 220. The mounting arms 220 may include a plurality of holes 226 at set intervals, for example, three centimetres (one inch), to permit incremental adjustment in height. The support rails 230 may be attached to the mounting arms 220 by self-tapping screws.

Other coupling devices may provide screws, rivets, plugs, and the like. The support rails 230 may be attached with cleat 232 facing outward, away from the wall. Preferably, the first and second support rails 230a and 230b are utilized and preferably spaced the maximum distance apart to increase stability of the system 200. Once the mounting system 200 is fully assembled, the board may be hung from cleat 232 of the upper support rail 230a.

In an exemplary embodiment, the board may hang from the upper support rail 230a by corresponding features included on the top of the whiteboard. The lower support rail 230b may be attached to the board with double-faced tape. Once the position of the support rails 230 and mounting arms 220 are in the desired location. Double-faced tape is adhered between the lower support rail 230b and the whiteboard. The board is then pressed firmly to the lower support rail 230b to properly secure the connection. Alternatively, hook and loop fasteners may be used in place of the adhesive for a secure, but non-permanent coupling. Further, other fastening means may be employed to removably attach the board to the support rails 230a and b.

In an exemplary embodiment, hook and loop fasteners may be utilized used to increase the connection between the mounting system 200 and the supporting wall. Coin-shaped, hook fasteners may be adhered to the supporting wall or existing blackboard with double-faced tape, while the corresponding loop fastener may be adhered to the leveling foot 224. The hook and loop fasteners may be adhered by taping, gluing, bonding, or some other device.

In yet another exemplary embodiment, finger cleats (not shown in Fig. 2) may be utilized to secure the base of the mounting system 200 to the supporting wall. Once the mounting system 200 is hung, assembled, and positioned, the finger cleat may slide around the leveling foot 224 and be secured to the supporting wall. The finger cleat is secured to the wall using the appropriate wall anchor and screw 234, depending on the support wall characteristics. The finger cleat may also be adhered to the supporting wall, or existing chalkboard, such as by taping, bonding, gluing, and the like.

Another exemplary embodiment includes a permanently affixed wall mounted rail system 200 for interactive whiteboards. The system 200 is composed of a top hanging rail 210 and two support rails, two mounting arms 220 with leveling feet and mounting clip. The rail system semi-permanently attaches an interactive whiteboard to a wall. The top hanging rail 210 is permanently mounted to a wall with the appropriate fasteners. The mounting arms 210 are hung from the hanging rail 210 on the clip affixed to the top of the mounting arm 220. The two remaining support rails are attached to the mounting arms 220 with screws. The interactive whiteboard mounts to a cleat on the top support rail. Two hook and loop tabs 226 are attached with double-face tape to the leveling feet 224 at the bottom of the mounting arms 220 and secured to the wall. Two hook and loop tabs 226 are attached to the lower support rail 230b and secured to the back of the interactive whiteboard. In one embodiment, the mounting arm 220 includes a series of screw holes 234 to allow for height adjustment.

Although embodiments of this invention have been fully described with reference to the accompanying drawings, it is to be noted that various changes and modifications will become apparent to those skilled in the art. Such changes and modifications are to be understood as being included within the scope of the claimed invention.

claim.claim-text: Montagesystem (100) zum Stützen einer Anzeige an einer Tragefläche, wobei das System aufweist: eine Kopfschiene (110), die zum Befestigen an der Tragefläche ausgebildet ist; eine Vielzahl an Montagearmen (120), die lösbar befestigt sind, indem sie an der Kopfschiene hängen, wobei jeder Montagearm ein erstes Ende und ein zweites Ende aufweist, jeder Arm eine Längsachse aufweist, jeder Arm bei seinem zweiten Ende einen Abschnitt aufweist, der in Richtung der Tragefläche gebogen ausgebildet ist, um sie zu stützen, und jeder Arm einen Nivellierfuß (124) aufweist, der sich von den jeweiligen Schlussenden der zweiten Enden erstreckt, um für jeden Montagearm eine Stützung gegen die Tragefläche vorzusehen; und eine obere Stützschiene (130), die an der Vielzahl an Montagearmen lösbar befestigt ist und zum Stützen der Anzeige ausgebildet ist.

Montagesystem nach Anspruch 1, das ferner aufweist: an jedem der Vielzahl an Montagearmen ist ein Befestigungsabschnitt (122) befestigt, um jeden der Vielzahl an Montagearmen von der Kopfschiene hängen zu lassen.
Montagesystem nach Anspruch 2, bei dem der Befestigungsabschnitt ein Clip (226) ist, der von einer Stütze auf der Kopfschiene runterhängt.

Montagesystem nach einem der vorstehenden Ansprüche, bei dem jeder Nivellierfuß (124) eine Anpassung eines jeweiligen Montagearms relativ zu dem Abstand zwischen der Tragefläche und der Anzeige erlaubt.
Montagesystem nach Anspruch 4, das ferner aufweist: eine Fingerstütze (140), die zum Befestigen an der Tragefläche und Sichern des Nivellierungsfußes in seiner Position ausgebildet ist.

Montagesystem nach Anspruch 4, das ferner aufweist: eine Vielzahl an Fingerstützen (140), die zum Befestigen der Tragefläche ausgebildet sind und dazu ausgelegt sind, die Vielzahl an Montagearmen an der Stelle zu sichern.
Montagesystem nach einem der vorstehenden Ansprüche, bei dem die Vielzahl an Montagearmen eine Vielzahl an Kopplungsstellen zum Einstellen einer Höhe der oberen Stützschiene aufweisen.
Montagesystem nach einem der vorstehenden Ansprüche, bei dem die obere Stützschiene eine weitere Stütze (132) zum Stützen der Anzeige aufweist.
Montagesystem nach einem der vorstehenden Ansprüche, das ferner aufweist: eine untere Stützschiene (130b), die direkt an der Vielzahl an Montagearmen befestigt ist.
Montagesystem nach Anspruch 9, bei dem die untere Stützschiene mit einem Klettverschluss an der Anzeige lösbar befestigt ist.
Montagesystem nach Anspruch 9, bei dem die untere Stützschiene mit einem Haftmittel an der Anzeige lösbar befestigt ist.
Montagesystem nach einem der vorstehenden Ansprüche, bei dem die Anzeige eine interaktive Weißwandtafel ist.

Montagesystem nach einem der vorstehenden Ansprüche, das ferner eine untere Stützschiene (130b) aufweist, wobei die oberen und unteren Stützschienen (130a, 130b) jeweils eine im Wesentlichen flache Basis, die mit einer sich zwischen der Vielzahl an Montagearmen erstreckenden Länge und einer Höhe die größer ist als eine Tiefe der Montagearme, entlang einer mit der Vielzahl an Montagearmen in Kontakt stehenden Fläche, positioniert ist, und eine weitere Stütze (132) aufweisen, die sich von jeder der im Wesentlichen flachen Basen erstreckt, um einen nach oben gedrehten Flansch zu bilden, und wobei die Kopfschiene eine im Wesentlichen flache Basis mit einem Stützvorsprung (112) zum Aufhängen der Vielzahl an Montagearmen und Stopper an beiden Enden des Stützvorsprungs aufweist, um die Vielzahl an Montagearmen entlang einer Länge des Stützvorsprungs zu halten.

A mounting system (100) for supporting a display to a support surface, the system comprising: a top rail (110) configured for attachment to the support surface; a plurality of mounting arms (120) removably attached, by hanging, to the top rail, each mounting arm comprising a first end and a second end, each arm having a longitudinal axis, each arm having a portion at the second end thereof that is curved towards the support surface to support them and each arm including a leveling foot (124) extending from respective terminal ends of the second ends to provide support for each mounting arm against the support surface; and an upper support rail (130) removably attached to the plurality of mounting arms and configured to support the display.
The mounting system of claim 1, further comprising: an attachment portion (122) is attached to each of the plurality of mounting arms to hang each of the plurality of mount arms from the top rail.
The mounting system of claim 2, wherein the attachment portion is a clip (226) that hangs from a cleat on the top rail.
The mounting system of any preceding claim, wherein each leveling foot (124) allows adjustment of its respective mounting arm relative to the distance between the support surface and the display.
The mounting system of claim 4, further comprising: a finger cleat (140) configured to attach to the support surface and secure the leveling foot in position.
The mounting system of claim 4, further comprising: a plurality of finger cleats (140) configured to attach to the support surface and designed to secure the plurality of mounting arms in place.
The mounting system of any preceding claim, wherein the plurality of mounting arms include a plurality of coupling locations to adjust a height of the upper support rail.
The mounting system of any preceding claim, wherein the upper support rail includes another cleat (132) to support the display.
The mounting system of any preceding claim, further comprising: a lower support rail (130b) directly attached to the plurality of mounting arms.
The mounting system of claim 9, wherein the lower support rail is removably attached to the display with a hook and loop fastener.
The mounting system of claim 9, wherein the lower support rail is removably attached to the display with an adhesive.
The mounting system of any preceding claim, wherein the display is an interactive whiteboard.

The mounting system of any preceding claim, further comprising a lower support rail (130b), wherein the upper and lower support rails (130a, 130b) each comprise a substantially flat base positioned with a length extending between the plurality of mounting arms and a height, along a surface contacting the plurality of mounting arms, greater than a depth from the mounting arm, and another cleat (132) extending from each of the substantially flat bases to create an upward-turned flange, and wherein the top rail comprises a substantially flat base including a support protrusion (112) to hang the plurality of mounting arms end stops at both ends of the support protrusion to maintain the plurality of mounting arms along a length of the support protrusion.

Système de montage (100) pour supporter un affichage sur une surface de support, le système comprenant : un rail supérieur (110) configuré pour fixation à la surface de support : une pluralité de bras de montage (120) fixés amoviblement, par suspension, au rail supérieur, chaque bras de montage comprenant une première extrémité et une seconde extrémité, chaque bras ayant un axe longitudinal, chaque bras ayant une partie à la seconde extrémité de celui-ci qui est courbée vers la surface de support pour les supporter et chaque bras incluant un pied de mise à niveau (124) s'étendant des extrémités terminales respectives des secondes extrémités pour servir de support à chaque bras de montage contre la surface de support ; et un rail de support supérieur (130) fixé amoviblement à la pluralité de bras de montage et configuré pour supporter l'affichage.

Système de montage selon la revendication 1, comprenant en outre : une partie de fixation (122) est attachée à chaque pluralité de bras de montage pour suspendre chaque pluralité de bras de montage au rail supérieur.
Système de montage selon la revendication 2, dans lequel la partie de fixation est une pince (226) pendant à un taquet du rail supérieur.

Système de montage selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel chaque pied de mise à niveau (124) permet d'ajuster ses bras de montage respectifs par rapport à la distance entre la surface de support et l'affichage.
Système de montage selon la revendication 4, comprenant en outre : un taquet à doigts (140) configuré pour s'attacher à la surface de support et sécuriser le pied de mise à niveau en position.

Système de montage selon la revendication 4, comprenant en outre : une pluralité de taquets à doigts (140) configurés pour s'attacher à la surface de support et conçus pour sécuriser la pluralité de bras de montage en position.

Système de montage selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel la pluralité de bras de montage inclut une pluralité d'emplacements de couplage pour ajuster une hauteur du rail de support supérieur.
Système de montage selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel le rail de support supérieur inclut un autre taquet (132) pour supporter l'affichage.
Système de montage selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, comprenant en outre : un rail de support inférieur (130b) directement attaché à la pluralité de bras de montage.
Système de montage selon la revendication 9, dans lequel le rail de support inférieur est attaché amoviblement à l'affichage avec une fixation de type boucle et crochet.
Système de montage selon la revendication 9, dans lequel le rail de support inférieur est attaché amoviblement à l'affichage avec un adhésif.
Système de montage selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel l'affichage est un tableau blanc interactif.

Système de montage selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, comprenant en outre un rail de support inférieur (130b), dans lequel les rails de support inférieur et supérieur (130a, 130b) comprennent chacun une base sensiblement plate positionnée avec une longueur s'étendant entre la pluralité de bras de montage et une hauteur, le long de la surface en contact avec la pluralité de bras de montage, plus grande qu'une profondeur du bras de montage, et un autre taquet (132) s'étendant de chacune des bases sensiblement plates pour créer une bride tournée vers le haut, et dans lequel le rail supérieur comprend une base sensiblement plate incluant une saillie de support (112) pour suspendre la pluralité de butées d'extrémité de bras de montage des deux côtés de la saillie de support pour maintenir la pluralité de bras de montage le long de la longueur de la saillie de support.
